title: Does the United States rank first in the world in oil consumption?
text: Richard Ojeda, former Senator of West Virginia, who briefly sought to nominate the Democratic Party for President, used Twitter to participate in several areas where he said that the United States was leading the world -- but not in a good way. Ojeda told Polyte Fact West Virginia that he had found his information through Wikipedia. We've become original sources. Compared to total oil consumption, the United States ranks first in the world, according to the World Energy Statistical Review 2019, a comprehensive review of global energy data. In 2018, the United States consumed 20,456,000 barrels per day - much more than the second-class country, China, with 13,525,000 barrels per day. It should be noted, however, that the use of the total consumption figure is an incomplete method of measuring global oil consumption "for two factors - high consumption and population size," said Anna Mikulska, a non-resident colleague at the Centre for Energy Studies at the Baker Public Policy Institute of Rice University. Because larger countries will normally have larger aggregates than smaller countries, it is also important to look at per capita consumption - consumption divided by population. With this measure, the United States is close to the top, but not quite so. 1. According to Ene, an Italian oil company, the United States ranked third internationally in per capita oil consumption. Saudi Arabia ranks first with 34.91 barrels per year, followed by Canada with 24.16 barrels and the United States with 23.12 barrels.
